items.content_html: Today was unexpectedly full of proposal work for me. I think I need to help revamp how we write proposals at my firm. It was so hectic and we could have done better if we had more time.

The New York Times crossword puzzle app and, of course, Micro.blog, have now taken over the time I had previously allotted to Twitter. My mental state is much better, though I am starting think of all words in terms of how many letters are in them.
I really liked this back-to-basics post by John Sundell about type composition in Swift. I think lots of programming tutorial writersâ€”and readersâ€”fail to focus on fundamentals. John does not.
SwiftoDo 2.7.0 is now available in the App Store. It vastly improves the loading speed for huge task lists, and adds URL support (long-press a task to open any URL it contains).
60Â° F and 20 MPH winds have made it both too warm and too cold for a proper Winterfest for us today.
I submitted SwiftoDo 2.7.0 to the App Store earlier today, and tonight I made enough bug fixes and library updates to warrant a version 2.7.1 soon thereafter.

I am too busy coding tonight to order a HomePod. The audiophile part of me really wants one, though. I have a fancy BeoPlay M3 speaker already, but I think the HomePod has cooler tech and is just large enough to sound a whole lot better.

I did some complicated sampling today. ACLâ€™s new APPEND command made short work of combining 4 tables, which sounds like nothing, but it has long been a weak point in ACLâ€™s functionality. Itâ€™s a welcome improvement.

I diagnosed and fixed a memory leak in my iOS app using Instruments and Xcodeâ€™s memory debugger for the first time tonight. It almost made sense to me. My fix involved removing retain cycles by getting rid of a closure and turning one of my classes into a struct.

ðŸ“š I resumed reading Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln last night. Itâ€™s an incredibly well-written and well-researched book. I had stopped reading it because I thought its subject matterâ€”the break-up of the United States due to intractable racial prejudiceâ€”hit a little too close to home for 2017-18. Regardless, I am now continuing.
